newsitem.title: BELGIUM: French clock-change plan gets EU airing.
newsitem.headline: French clock-change plan gets EU airing.

text.p: A rumbling row over France's plans to scrap a twice-yearly change to its clocks is set to come to a head on Tuesday at the start of the March 11/12 Transport Council.

At issue will be the European Commission's proposal to synchronise EU countries' switch between summer and winter time, a practice which puts clocks forward one hour each March and back in October to provide longer, lighter summer evenings.
Specifically, that would involve discussions on proposal COM(96)106 for an eighth summertime directive.

"France has expressly said that she has difficulties with harmonisation," a Dutch diplomat told a news conference on Friday, adding that Paris wanted an opt-out from the plan to allow it to scrap the switch.

French Prime Minister Alain Juppe irked several EU partners when he announced the plan in September, citing public opposition to what he said were disruptive changes long-opposed by farmers and found by some French economists to cost more than they generate in energy savings from lighter evenings.
Southern EU countries like Greece, Italy, Spain and Portugal have argued that longer evenings boost their busy tourist trades, allowing museums and other services to stay open longer.

Fourteen of the EU's 15 countries want harmonised clock changes, an easy qualified majority under the co-decision procedure, for which the parliament has already adopted an amendment in its first reading which backed France's position.
But the Dutch presidency are reluctant to force the issue, mindful of the traditional leeway granted to countries with particular political difficulties with a new piece of EU law.

"(With) this type of issue, where sovereignty is very much involved, I think the normal inclination of a presidency is to get unanimity," he said, adding that the Netherlands' goal on Tuesday would be to bring "clarity" to the issue.
Failure to agree new rules before the end of the year will leave a legal limbo for 1998, creating confusion for timetable planners in schools and scheduled transport businesses.
In the absence of binding rules, countries would be free to do what they wanted, which for the majority would mean keeping the practice of stepping in time.
The legal void would mean France could keep the same time all year round although it has not yet decided whether that will be GMT plus one or two hours.
